overview: The purpose of this measure is to appropriate funds for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative and to establish and appropriate funds into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund to assist the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation. [3] [3] This measure represents a critical step forward in meeting the housing needs of Hawaii's most vulnerable populations by providing additional funds for the Kauhale Initiative and enabling the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. [3] The amended measure also inserts language that appropriates an unspecified amount to assist the Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions in implementing the Kauhale Initiative. [3]
appropriations: Your Committee has amended this measure by changing the appropriations to unspecified amounts. [3] The Committee on Finance is respectfully requested to consider an appropriation amount of $50,000,000 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for the continued operation of the Kauhale Initiative and $12,000,000 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) to be deposited into and out of the Supportive Housing Special Fund. [3] This includes a requested $11,810,250 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for the financing of the development, operation, and maintenance of affordable, supportive housing projects and $189,750 (HB431_HD1_HSCR3_.htm.txt) for the establishment and hiring of one temporary full-time equivalent Housing Finance Specialist I. [3] [3]
assumptions_and_methodology: The measure is supported by assumptions of cost-effectiveness, with testimony indicating Kauhale costs are around $30,000 (HB431_TESTIMONY_HSH_01-28-25_.PDF.txt) per person per year, compared to incarceration costs of $112,000 (HB431_TESTIMONY_HSH_01-28-25_.PDF.txt) for each resident per year. [2] Another estimate suggests the cost to care for a homeless person not in stable housing is an average of $82,000 (HB431_TESTIMONY_HSH_01-28-25_.PDF.txt) per person per year. [2] Furthermore, a study by Partners in Care is cited, which revealed that the recidivism rate for individuals who received housing support was just 12.8% versus 50% without housing support. [2]
agency_impact: The Supportive Housing Special Fund will be administered by the Hawai‘i Housing and Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC). [2] The Committee on Finance is requested to consider funding for one temporary full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Housing Finance Specialist I within the HHFDC to help with administration of the special fund. [3] The Statewide Office on Homelessness and Housing Solutions (SOHHS) requested one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Return to Home Homelessness Assistant position to help with the administration of the Return to Home Program statewide. [2]
economic_impact: This bill is expected to dramatically reduce the jail population and recidivism at a significantly lower cost than incarceration. [2] A study by Partners in Care revealed that the recidivism rate for individuals in Hawai'i who received housing support was just 12.8% versus 50% without housing support. [2] By addressing housing insecurity and ensuring access to integrated support services, the measure will enable individuals with I/DD to live more independently and with dignity, reduce reliance on costly institutional care or emergency services, and improve overall health. [2] [2]
policy_impact: Your Committee has amended this measure by deleting language that would have established the Kauhale Initiative Special Fund. [3] The measure establishes the Supportive Housing Special Fund to be administered by the Hawai‘i Housing and Finance and Development Corporation to facilitate the development of mixed-income rental housing projects. [2] The committee also deleted language that attempted to prevent the proper lapse of a general fund appropriation at the end of the fiscal biennium for which the appropriation was made. [3]
revenue_sources: House Bill (H.B.) No. 431 appropriates $50,000,000 (HB431_TESTIMONY_HSH_01-28-25_.PDF.txt) in general funds in both FY 26 and FY 27 for the Kauhale Initiative. [2] The bill also appropriates $12,000,000 (HB431_TESTIMONY_HSH_01-28-25_.PDF.txt) in general funds in both FY 26 and FY 27 for deposit into the Supportive Housing Special Fund. [2] The Department of Budget and Finance noted that pursuant to the Constitution of the State of Hawai‘i, no general fund appropriation shall be made for a period exceeding three years. [2]
